node.title: As Ghislaine Maxwell’s Trial Begins, Epstein’s Shadow Looms Large
node.alt: Ghislaine Maxwell, long a fixture on New York City’s social scene, is accused of procuring and grooming girls as young as 14 for the disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein.
node.description: Ms. Maxwell’s sex trafficking trial in Manhattan, which starts on Monday, is widely seen as a proxy for the courtroom reckoning that her longtime partner never received.
node.content: ["On the first floor of the federal courthouse in Manhattan hangs an unusual art exhibit: framed courtroom illustrations of terrorists, mobsters and corrupt politicians with names like Yousef, Gotti and Silver who had all appeared before judges there.", "For a while, one of the most notorious faces on display, in a corridor near a room where prospective jurors gather, was that of Jeffrey Epstein, the disgraced financier and sex offender.", "But at a recent hearing in the case of Ghislaine Maxwell, whose trial on charges she helped Mr. Epstein recruit and ultimately abuse young girls begins on Monday, the government and the defense each asked that Mr. Epstein\u2019s picture be removed from the wall.", "Judge Alison J. Nathan agreed to have it done. But Mr. Epstein, who died by suicide more than two years ago, will not be so easily erased from the trial of Ms. Maxwell, his longtime partner.", "\u201cThe shadow of Epstein is going to loom large here,\u201d said Moira Penza, a former federal prosecutor in Brooklyn. \u201cThe case is obviously going to be about Maxwell, but he\u2019s going to be right at the center of it as well.\u201d", "Ms. Maxwell, 59, the daughter of a British media mogul and a longtime fixture on New York\u2019s social scene, had been linked to Mr. Epstein as a girlfriend and later helped him manage his homes and his social relationships.", "Her lawyers now face the challenge of trying to disentangle her from the allegations against Mr. Epstein \u2014 even perhaps portraying her as his victim, legal experts said. But the government will also have to tread carefully before the jury.", "\u201cThe prosecutors are certainly going to want to paint a picture of Epstein as an evil man, because that\u2019s necessary for the jurors to understand and be outraged by her role in the scheme,\u201d said Arlo Devlin-Brown, a former top federal corruption prosecutor in Manhattan.", "\u201cBut they really have to walk a fine line,\u201d he added, \u201cbetween setting that stage and going overboard \u2014 making the trial too much about Epstein and his conduct, and not enough about Maxwell.\u201d", "Mr. Epstein, 66, was arrested on July 6, 2019, and charged with recruiting dozens of girls to engage in sex acts with him at his mansion in Manhattan and his estate in Palm Beach, Fla. He paid them hundreds of dollars in cash for each encounter, a federal indictment said.", "Just over a month later, Mr. Epstein hanged himself in his jail cell while awaiting trial, the medical examiner ruled.", "In announcing charges against Ms. Maxwell in July 2020, prosecutors said she had been a critical facilitator of Mr. Epstein\u2019s conduct.", "\u201cMaxwell enticed minor girls, got them to trust her and then delivered them into the trap that she and Jeffrey Epstein had set,\u201d Audrey Strauss, then the acting Manhattan U.S. attorney, said at the time.", "Ms. Maxwell\u2019s lawyer did not respond to a request for comment on her client\u2019s behalf, but in a recent hearing, Ms. Maxwell told Judge Nathan, \u201cI have not committed any crime.\u201d", "A federal indictment charged Ms. Maxwell had groomed girls to lower their defenses, befriending them by asking about their lives, their schools and families and taking them to the movies and shopping. The term \u201cgrooming\u201d describes a strategy that predators use to try to break down a potential victim\u2019s resistance to abusive conduct.", "Having developed a rapport with a victim, Ms. Maxwell would try to normalize sexual abuse by discussing sexual topics, undressing in front of a victim or being present for sex acts involving the girl and Mr. Epstein, the indictment said.", "It said that her presence \u201chelped put the victims at ease because an adult woman was present.\u201d", "Ms. Maxwell\u2019s lawyers have not publicly discussed their trial strategy, but shortly after her arrest, when she was unsuccessfully seeking bail, they wrote to Judge Nathan: \u201cSometimes, the simplest point is the most critical one: Ghislaine Maxwell is not Jeffrey Epstein.\u201d", "Rachel E. Barkow, a professor of criminal law at New York University School of Law, said it will be a challenge for Ms. Maxwell \u201cto try to somehow separate herself from him, and make the case that she\u2019s a different person and just because she has a relationship with him does not mean guilt by association.\u201d", "Ms. Penza, who led the prosecuting team that won the 2019 racketeering conviction of Keith Raniere, the Nxivm sex cult leader, said Ms. Maxwell\u2019s lawyers might try to suggest that she was a victim of Mr. Epstein, blaming him without fear that he could rebut the assertion \u2014 a kind of \u201cempty chair\u201d defense.", "\u201cYou couldn\u2019t have a bigger empty chair than in this case,\u201d Ms. Penza said. \u201cEveryone in the room is going to be navigating the fact that Epstein is not on trial and Maxwell is.\u201d", "Mr. Devlin-Brown added that \u201cthe defense will need to be deft in their portrayal of Epstein.\u201d If her lawyers want to portray Ms. Maxwell as a dupe, he said, they may focus on Mr. Epstein\u2019s \u201cmanipulative traits, his ability to charm and fool high-profile individuals from the worlds of politics, academia and commerce.\u201d", "Prosecutors have already pushed back on a potential Maxwell-as-victim defense, calling such an argument \u201cbaseless\u201d and asking that her lawyers be precluded from making it without first showing the judge how they would prove it.", "\u201cThe government\u2019s yearslong investigation has not developed any evidence that the defendant was victimized in any way by Jeffrey Epstein,\u201d the government recently wrote in little-noticed court papers.", "The prosecutors said that even before they presented Ms. Maxwell\u2019s case before the grand jury, they listened as her defense lawyers made various arguments trying to dissuade them from charging her.", "\u201cAt no time has the defense represented to the government that Epstein victimized the defendant in any manner,\u201d the prosecutors wrote.", "And when prosecutors more recently asked Ms. Maxwell\u2019s lawyers whether they planned to offer such evidence at trial, \u201cdefense counsel declined to answer,\u201d the government said.", "In a tart response to the government\u2019s assertions, Ms. Maxwell\u2019s lawyers suggested that there was indeed evidence for such an argument.", "\u201cThe government should reread the many thousands of pages of witness statements,\u201d the defense wrote, \u201cbefore asserting that it would be \u2018baseless\u2019 to claim that Ms. Maxwell was a victim of Epstein.\u201d", "\u201cThe government would like nothing better than for the court to require defense counsel to have their hands tied behind their back and their mouths duct-taped,\u201d the defense added.", "Whatever the defense\u2019s strategy, Ms. Maxwell\u2019s lawyers also will be fighting a perception that she is Mr. Epstein\u2019s proxy \u2014 that her trial will be the one he never had.", "Mr. Epstein first avoided federal sex-trafficking charges in 2007 when he negotiated a secret deal with the U.S. attorney\u2019s office in Miami to plead guilty to lesser state charges of soliciting a minor for prostitution. He avoided another trial when he died by suicide in 2019.", "\u201cThe fact I will never have a chance to face my predator in court eats away at my soul,\u201d one of Mr. Epstein\u2019s accusers, Jennifer Araoz, said in a court hearing shortly after Mr. Epstein's death. She had accused Mr. Epstein of raping her when she was a 15-year-old performing arts high school student in New York.", "The judge in Mr. Epstein\u2019s case, Richard M. Berman, had called the hearing after prosecutors asked him to dismiss Mr. Epstein\u2019s indictment because of his death. Judge Berman did so, but only after giving nearly two dozen of Mr. Epstein\u2019s accusers a chance to be heard in court.", "\u201cPlease, please finish what you have started,\u201d another of Mr. Epstein\u2019s accusers, Sarah Ransome, said at the hearing, thanking prosecutors for \u201cpursuing justice on behalf of the victims.\u201d ", "As for the picture of Mr. Epstein, who was sketched seated between his lawyers at a 2019 bail hearing, it was taken down as the parties requested.", "\u201cMy sense is both sides want to ensure there\u2019s going to be a fair trial,\u201d said Deirdre von Dornum, the head of the federal defenders office in Brooklyn.", "She said prosecutors would not want the defense to later be able to seek a mistrial on grounds a juror was influenced by the Epstein sketch. And Ms. Maxwell\u2019s attorneys would not want a juror thinking, \u201cHe\u2019s so notorious that he\u2019s hanging on the wall.\u201d", "\u201cIt\u2019ll remind the jurors,\u201d she said, \u201cthat his trial never happened and that he was never brought to justice, so someone still needs to be.\u201d"]
